awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Using noble gas techniques to benchmark feldspar thermoluminescence (TL) thermochronology
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Nathan Brown has been granted a postdoctoral fellowship to carry out research and an education plan with at the Berkeley Geochronology Center. The main goal of this project is to develop feldspar thermoluminescence (TL) for use as an ultra-low-temperature thermochronometer. Once validated, this technique will allow geologists to: infer recent temperature perturbations caused by geomorphic agents acting within the upper kilometer or two of Earth's surface; resolve local Holocene uplift rates and better evaluate seismic risk in tectonically active regions; and survey sites for their potential geothermal energy resources. Dr. Brown will also interact with and train undergraduate and graduate students in the sample preparation and data analysis techniques necessary to implement this novel technique.

The spatial and temporal scales over which rivers and glaciers erode bedrock are largely inaccessible to thermochronologists. Feldspar TL thermochronology, however, shows sensitivity to near-surface and atmospheric temperatures and can be used to constrain continuous thermal histories at timescales ranging from about 100 to 1,000,000 years. This study will calibrate feldspar TL results against results obtained with the more established techniques of paleothermometry from cosmogenic 3He in quartz and apatite 4He/3He thermochronology. Bedrock samples that will be analyzed come from the Yucaipa Ridge tectonic block, adjacent to the San Andreas fault; the Klinaklini glacial valley in British Columbia; and the Pensacola Mountains of Antarctica.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project NSF EAR-PF 1806629 was an NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship to PI Nathan D. Brown, in collaboration with sponsoring scientist, David L. Shuster, at the University of California, Berkeley. This fellowship supported an early career scientist through research projects, outreach opportunities, and professional development activities.

The primary research goal of this project was to refine a new method, thermoluminescence thermochronology, to analyze the recent thermal history of bedrock samples, with an emphasis on resolving landscape evolution. To achieve this, bedrock samples were collected across multiple fault strands of the southern San Andreas fault zone. Thermoluminescence measurements from this project revealed significant differences in tectonic uplift across some fault strands and not others. This finding represents a new way to detect seismic hazard in regions with significant tectonic uplift. This is important in southern California, because few alternative techniques exist for constraining recent tectonic activity in steep, mountainous regions. This approach is currently being applied to other potentially active fault strands in this region. In addition to these site-specific results, this project resulted in two journal articles detailing how to estimate sample-specific luminescence properties needed to adopt this method in other settings so that other researchers can adopt the technique in the future.

Other research outcomes include a publication and an accompanying suite of open-source MATLAB functions that allow the geomorphology community to numerically model how various luminescence signals will evolve under different scenarios. For example, these functions could test how a wildfire, or transportation within a stream, or exhumation within an uplifting tectonic block, would imprint the luminescence signals within a sand grain or cobble.

This project also supported the first application of luminescence surface exposure dating to subglacial bedrock in Antarctica. This published study reveals a Holocene history of ice sheet thinning and subsequent thickening for the Thwaites Glacier, an area of critical importance under future climatic warming scenarios. This approach is now being adopted elsewhere in Antarctica and Greenland.

Results from this project were disseminated to the public in several ways. PI Brown participated in the Popping the Science Bubble series at the Berkeley Public Library, and the Skype a Scientist program, which partners scientists with US K-12 classrooms for presentations. He also worked with the Dallas Fort Worth Airport to develop an Earth Day Video that was distributed to local classrooms. He presented his work on the Landscapes Live seminar series, a weekly webinar hosted by the European Geophysical Union and made available to the public on YouTube.

During this fellowship, PI Brown was hired as an assistant professor in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences at the University of Texas, Arlington. The fellowship supported the PI to receive training at the Early Career Geoscience Faculty Workshop, a workshop intended to develop young faculty members into more effective geoscience educators and researchers. Based on expertise gained through this project, Brown has established a new luminescence dating laboratory at UTA, the first in the US to focus on luminescence thermochronology.
